If anything Sherman helped Earl and Kam more than they helped him because they didn't ever have to worry about an entire side of the field.

As a Falcons fan, even with 28-3 happening, I’m not sure I believed I’d ever see them even in a Super Bowl. I think that many teams being down helped. We were 7-5 at one point, but then we had the Rams and 49ers back to back, and then we won two fairly easy divisional games to finish 11-5. Without that easy couple of weeks against the Rams and 49ers, we might not have been in a position to make a run. Goes to show how who you play and when you play them can actually make a difference.

Let me put it this way. 2011 Gronk got injured before the SB. They lost a close game because he could only be used as a decoy 2012 they were one of the best teams, injured right before the AFCCG and they lose at home (only home home playoff loss in an AFCCG the Pats had this decade 2013 out most of the season and it’s the Pats worse season of the decade 2014, healthy and they win a SB2015, mostly healthy all year, the one game he is out is a loss that causes them homefield. Against an all time great defense in the AFCCG Brady starts spamming Gronk and makes what would have been a comeback if not for a missed extra point because they can’t stop him 2016: they pay Bennett a fortune as Gronk insurance just in case. 2017. Gronk is healthy they are dominant, Brady wins MVP and they break passing records in the SB. Defense is the reason they lose despite and amazing performance 2018 Gronk is banged up beyond belief. He finally gets healthy by playoff time, team is totally different and runs through the playoffs. Gronk makes game changing SB play 2019 is the only other year this decade that Gronk is not there for most of besides 2013. Is considered the other worst Pats season this decade. Yes Gronk had health issues. SB’s however were however won and lost largely on his status and he was the biggest difference in success for the team. You could not say that about Gonzalez.

>The Chargers are taking Tyrod over him.You say that, but it could very well be (and seems likely) they plan to draft a QB. Tyrod has never been anything more than a bridge.>Dalton was pretty much worse than Trubisky last year and unless he gets the Belichick magic, he’s just Flacco 2.0.So was Foles, lol. The idea is that if you're willing to believe Foles will be better on a different team, so can Dalton. >Foles has a 2:1 QB/INT ratio in his career,Do you think that's because he's genuinely good or because he got the flukiest season of all time and every major stat predicted a massive regression (which came) and hasn't been very good since. [Here's an article from 2014 describing it.](http://thecomeback.com/thisgivensunday/2014-articles/was-nick-foles-2013-season-a-fluke.html)Even if it wasn't a fluke, his prowess since then has proven he cannot sustain that success with any degree of certainty, because his famous 2:1 ratio in every other year combined becomes 44:33, or 4:3. If that were truly him, why can't he maintain those stats? I know you're going to give me that bullshit about him being on a bunch of bad teams, but that doesn't explain his mediocrity in 2018 nor why guys like Case Keenum and Minshew are able to play much better on the worse or the same teams, respectively. The only answer I can seem to get is that Foles has a play style that requires him to have a **lot** of surrounding pieces, which is an elegant way of saying he fucking sucks. Case was decent in 2017 on that stacked Vikings team but you don't see people banging the drum for him to start anywhere. He also played much better with that awful Redskins team than Foles did here on a purely efficiency basis; higher TD%, higher ANY/A, higher Qb rating, lower sack %, with all the other efficiency stats being either close or functionally irrelevant (Foles had a higher cmp% by 1 point but they're both well above 60 so who gives a fuck). Don't even get me started on Minshew.So what does that mean? It means that a QB that is good selectively and only with a great team is what most people would call a very shitty quarterback, but because he got hot at the right time people will throw themselves in front of him as a meat shield despite him more than earning his reputation as a failure.>You know this thing will probably bleeds into OTA’s right? It’s not gonna be a lot of timeDidn't realize QB's had to be there physically to learn the playcalling. Don't say it's chemistry between the receivers, either, because Foles doesn't have that either; playing games with someone once doesn't mean shit as evidenced by how Foles accomplished nothing with Conley here but Minshew really lifted him up.

Jerome Bettis fumbling near the goal line against the Colts in the 2005 AFC Divisional Playoff. The defense had essentially ended the game on the previous play, but Bettis awakened the Colts from the dead with an untimely fumble. I've been watching the Steelers since 1993, and I've never experienced such an emotional roller-coaster ride as I did late in that game.

And that play alone is what *got* him on the list. He was a very good RB, but not HoF or All-Decade, imo. His turbo effort on every play (illustrated in plays like BeastQuake) and his quirky Super Bowl antics built a lot of hype around him.  But his actually production wasn't that insane. He had 4 really good years, but his career YPC was also 4.2 (with 5 seasons *under* 4 yards a carry). To put that in perspective, his career YPC would have been 33rd in the league last year.

> Find me one instance of a team that moved from a city with a bigger market to a smaller market.The Rams went from LA to St. Louis but are now back in LA. The Raiders went from LA to Oakland, but they also started in Oakland. The Raiders also just moved to LV. There is also the SuperSonics moving to OKC.I fully understand the overall point you are making. Detroit is a top 15 market. It also within driving distance of 3 other top 100 markets(Flint, Grand Rapids, Toldeo) and one just outside of the top 100(Lansing 112). And for the most part those all support Detroit sports. For those that are going to say Toledo is in ohio and they don't support Detroit sports. For the most part you are wrong. Toledo is closer to Detroit than it is Cleveland by ~60 miles. And they almost always get Detroit sports on TV over Cleveland sports because of that distance.
